column1: A regnal year is a year of the reign of a monarch. It is from the Latin regnum meaning kingdom or rule. Some of the oldest dating systems were in regnal years. A regnal year usually begins on the date of a monarch's accession to the throne. Year one is counted from day one to the end of the first year of a monarch's reign. Then a second year of rule
column3: and so on. They would not have a zero year of rule. It is displayed as an ordinal
column4: not a cardinal number.Every year of a monarch's reign falls within two calendar years
column5: unless the reign began on the first day of the calendar year. When converting a regnal year in history to a calendar year
column6: this can cause an error of one year. In England
column7: from the 10th century until the late 13th century
column8: the practice was to count the regnal year from the date of coronation. This was usually a later date than when a monarch was proclaimed king or queen.
